home.subtitle: I am MÃ­a Salazar, a Junior Front-end developer, passionate about web layout and a design lover.
home.textOne: However, all this is a cover, since in reality I am the superhero Miss! Important, the person who fights against the! Importants and watches over the good use of CSS in the world and the well optimized and reusable code.

contact.title: Contact me
contact.subtitle: As a superhero, I am always saving the world from here to there, but if you know of any injustice that I must intervene in, please do not hesitate to contact me.
contact.justice: Justice, and code well done, never sleep.
contact.how: How do we change the world today?
contact.name: Write your name
contact.what: What do you want to tell me?

superpower.title: Superpowers
superpower.subtitle: Among my long list of superpowers are these languages, technologies and skills:
superpower.textOne: In my values as a superhero I can also highlight the BEM Methodology, the Agile Methodology, the Mobile First and using of Flexbox and CSS Grid Layout.
superpower.textTwo: Like any good superhero, I also have some weaknesses.
superpower.bubble: Did you know that I am one of the greatest experts in propaganda in South Korea and North Korea?

error.title: Page not found
error.subtitle: It looks like Miss !important is not here right now, shes is saving the world

portfolio.title: Portfolio
portfolio.subtitle: A superhero is known more for his actions than for his words, for his Reactions than for his customs, for his Vuood ore than for his mistakes and for knowing how to look at situations from another Angulear.

awards.subtitle: Superheroes sacrificed to their cause often receive awards and recognition for their performance
awards.textOne: As Miss! Important I look after the welfare of all the peoples of the universe, so I have diverse interests besides my fight against the! Importants and my defense of the good code
awards.textTwo: Take a look at my medals and keys to the city with which they have given me, and click on them for more information.
